facts.text: Civil Appeal Nos. 1827 to 1830 of 1968 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal Nos. 1827 to 1830 of 1968. Appeals from the judgments

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgments and orders dated August 22, 23, 1967, and August 23, 1967 of Mysore High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgments and orders dated August 22, 23, 1967, and August 23, 1967 of the Mysore High Court in writ petitions Nos. 1967 of 1966, and 1968, 1969 and 2388 of 1966.

facts.text: Mysore High Court judgments in writ petitions Nos. 1967 of 1966, 1968 of 1966, 1969 of 1966, and 2388 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: in writ petitions Nos. 1967 of 1966, and 1968, 1969 and 2388 of 1966. Shyamlad Pappu, M. S. Ganesh and S. P. Nayar, for the appellants  in all the appeals . V. Gupte and A. V. Rangam, for respondent number 1  in all the appeals.

facts.text: Respondents served notice by Secretary of Bellary Market Committee to pay cess on groundnut seeds bought or sold in notified area.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents were served a numberice by the Secretary of the Bellary Market Committee established under the Act to pay the cess on groundnut seeds bought or sold in the numberified area of the Committee.

facts.text: Respondents failed to comply with demand for cess, complaints filed against them for contravention of s. 111 of the Act and rules and bye-laws.

anchor.surface_text: As the respondents failed to companyply with the demand companyplaints were filed against them for companytravention of s. 1 1 1  of the Act and of certain rules and bye-laws framed thereunder.

facts.text: Respondents filed writ petitions under Art. 226 challenging validity of cess levy.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents filed petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the validity of the levy of cess.

facts.text: Mysore High Court quashed the demand for cess holding it was sales tax and maximum rate already imposed under s.15 Central Sales Tax Act 1956 and s.54 Mysore Sales Tax Act 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court quashed the demand on the ground that what was being really demanded was the payment of sales tax and since the maximum rate of sales tax authorised by s. 15 of the Central Sales Tax Act 1956 read with s. 5 4  of the Mysore Sales Tax Act 1957 had already been imposed

facts.text: High Court directed refund of cess collected during three years preceding writ petition presentation.

anchor.surface_text: the Market Committee companyld number make any further or additional levy. A direction was also made for refund of the cess companylected during a period of three years preceding the date of the presentation of the writ petition.

facts.text: Madras Commercial Crops Market Act 1933 applicable to Bellary district of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: challenging the demand of a cess levied in exercise of the powers companyferred by s. 11 1  of the Madras Commercial Crops Market Act 1933- hereinafter called the Act--the provisions of which were applicable to the Bellary district of the State of Mysore.

facts.text: By Central Act 30 of 1953 (Andhra State Act), territory of Bellary district taluks other than Alur, Adoni, Rayadrug added to Mysore from Madras.

anchor.surface_text: By the Andhra State Act 1953  Central Act 30 of 1953  a part A State to be known as Andhra came into existence. By s. 4 of that Act there was added to the State of Mysore the territory which immediately before the appointed was companyprised in the Taluks of Bellary district other than Alur, Adoni and Rayadrug in the State of Mysore

facts.text: s.53 of Central Act 30 of 1953: laws in force before appointed day continue in territories added to Mysore until legislature provides otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: and the said territories thereupon ceased to form part of the State of Madras. By virtue of s. 53 of the Central Act 30 of 1953 all laws which were in force immediately before the appointed day in the territories which became a part of the State of Mysore were to companytinue to be in force until otherwise provided by the legislature of that State.

facts.text: Madras Act 33 of 1955 amended s.11(1) of the Act to levy cess by way of sales tax notwithstanding Madras General Sales Tax Act 1939.

anchor.surface_text: With a view to avoid the legality of the levy being questioned the Madras legislature amended s. 11 1  by Madras Act 33 of 1955. It was stated in the objects and reasons of the Bill, which was introduced in the legislative assembly of that State, that it was proposed to make it clear that the levy was a cess by way of sales tax and that it was in addition to the sales tax levied under the Madras General Sales Tax Act 1939 and was also subject to the provisions of Article 286 of the Constitution.

facts.text: 1955 amendment did not apply to Bellary district as it was no longer part of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: Since that part of Bellary district which had bnen included in the Mysore State by virtue of the Central Act 30 of 1953 was numberlonger a part of the State of Madras the above amendment made in 1955 did number apply there.

facts.text: States Reorganisation Act 1956 transferred South Kanara district (except Kollegal and certain areas) to Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: By the States Reorganisation Act 1956 the district of South Kanara, with the exception of the Taluk of Kollegal and certain other areas became part of the new State of Mysore.

facts.text: Mysore Amendment and Validation of Levy of Cess Act 1958 received assent on November 30, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The Madras Commercial Crops Market  Mysore Amendment and Validation of Levy of Cess  Act 1958 received the assent of the Governor on November 30, 1958.

facts.text: 1958 Act amended s.11(1) deemed effective from November 23, 1955 for Madras area, specifying rates for Arecanut and Coconut.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 2 of this amending Act, s. 11 of the Act was amended. Sub-s.  1  as in force in the Madras area was substituted and was to be deemed to have been substituted with effect from November 23, 1955. This sub- section was as follows- Notwithstanding anything companytained in the general sales tax law for the time being in force, the market companymittee shall levy a cess by way of sales tax on any companymercial crop bought or sold in the numberified area at the rates specified hereunder- Arecanut Coconut.

facts.text: Mysore Agricultural Produce Marketing Regulation Act, 1966 (Mysore Act 27 of 1966) published September 15, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The Mysore Agricultural Produce Marketing  Regulation  Act, 1966  Mysore Act 27 of 1966  was published in the Mysore Gazette on September 15, 1966.

facts.text: s.154 of 1966 Act repeals Madras Commercial Crops Market Act 1933 as in force in Bellary District and as in force in Madras Area separately.

anchor.surface_text: S. 154 of that Act which relates to Repeal and Savings is as follows Repeal and savings.  1  The Madras Com- mercial Crops Market Act, 1938  Madras Act XX of 1933  as in force in Bellary District, the Madras Commercial Crops Market Act, 1933  Madras Act XX of 1933 , as in force in the Madras Area are hereby repealed.

facts.text: Impugned proceedings relate to levy in Bellary district prior to 1966 Act.

anchor.surface_text: As the impugned proceedings relate to levy in the Bellary district of the State of Mysore for the year prior to the enactment the new Act of 1966

facts.text: Supreme Court holds 1958 amendment not applicable to Bellary district, confined to Madras Area (South Kanara except specified).

anchor.surface_text: We have numbermanner of doubt that the Bellary district which became a part of the State of Mysore as a result of the Central Act 30 of 1953 was governed by s. 11 1  of the Act as it stood at the time it had become applicable to that area by virtue of s. 53 of the aforesaid Central Act of 1953. The amendment made by the Mysore legislature in 1958 by which sub-s. 1  of II was substituted by a new section did number apply to the Bellary district

facts.text: Bellary Market Committee bye-laws approved May 1960, levy under bye-law 19 at 9 paise per kg for groundnut seeds.

anchor.surface_text: The bye-laws of the Bellary Market Committee which were, framed in exercise of the powers companyferred by S. 19 of the Act read with the Madras Commercial, Crops Market Rules 1948 give an indication that the Amending Act of 1958 was number applicable to the Bellary district. These by-laws were approved in May 1960.Under bye-law 19 the Market companymittee companyld levy fee or cess on the numberified crops or companymodities at the rates specified in the schedule. ... Under bye-law 19 the rate specified for groundnut seeds was 9 paise per kilogram.

facts.text: Notice by Market Committee used word 'cess' but demand relates to fee under original s.11(1).

anchor.surface_text: Under bye-law 19 the rate specified for groundnut seeds was 9 paise per kilogram. The numberice sent by the Market Committee making the demand from the respondents employed the word cess but that cannot stand in the way of it being held that the demand related to a fee which alone companyld be levied under S. 11 1  of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeals, remits cases to High Court to determine if levy is valid fee related to services.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals are allowed accordingly and the cases are remitted to the High Court for disposal.

issues.text: whether the amendment made in s. 11(1) by the amending Act of 1958 passed by the Mysore legislature was applicable to [Bellary district] or whether the amending provision was confined only to the Madras Area which meant the district of South Kanara with the exception of specified area which came to be incorporated in the State of Mysore in 1956

arguments.court_reasoning: 1958 amendment not applicable to Bellary district, so levy under original s.11(1) as fee, not sales tax

arguments.claim: Definition of 'Madras Area' in Mysore General Clauses Act s.3 cl.47 limited to South Kanara to be disregarded; Madras Area in 1958 Amending Act includes Bellary district

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the opinion that the definition contained in clause 47 of s. 3 of the Mysore General Clauses Act of Madras Area which was limited to the South Kanara district with the exception of specified areas had to be disregarded while interpreting the expression Madras Area occurring in the Mysore Amending Act of 1958.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 60.Under bye-law 19 the Market companymittee companyld levy fee or cess on the numberified crops or companymodities at the rates specified in the sche

arguments.court_reasoning: Definition applies; objects/reasons, s.154 1966 Act, bye-laws confirm distinction between Bellary and Madras Area

arguments.claim: Statement of objects and reasons of 1958 Bill mentions only Act as amended in 1955 in force in South Kanara district; changes confined to South Kanara Market Committee

anchor.surface_text: 1 In the statement of objects and reasons relating to the Madras Commercial Crops Markets Mysore Amendment and Validation of Levy of Cess Bill 1958 when it was introduced in the Mysore legislature there was mention only of the Act as amended by the Madras legislature in 1955 being in force in South Kanara district.

arguments.claim: 1958 Amending Act applicable only to 'Madras Area' meaning South Kanara district (per States Reorganisation Act adaptation and Mysore General Clauses Act definition), excluding Bellary added in 1953

anchor.surface_text: 2 The Amending Act of 1958 was made applicable only to what was called the Madras Area. This area could have reference only to the South Kanara district with the exception of the specified areas which was a part of the State of Madras immediately before the States Reorganisation Act of 1956.

arguments.claim: s.154 Mysore Act 27 of 1966 repeals Act 'as in force in Bellary District' and 'as in force in the Madras Area' separately, confirming distinction

anchor.surface_text: 3 The distinction between what may be called the Bellary Area and the Madras Area which came to be incorporated in the State of Mysore in 1953 and 1956 respectively is fully substantiated by s.154 of the Mysore Act 27 of 1966.

arguments.claim: Bye-laws of Bellary Market Committee (approved 1960) levy rates under s.19 for groundnut etc., exclude arecanut/coconut specified in 1958 Act, indicating 1958 Act not applicable to Bellary

anchor.surface_text: 4 The bye-laws of the Bellary Market Committee which were, framed in exercise of the powers conferred by S. 19 of the Act read with the Madras Commercial, Crops Market Rules 1948 give an indication that the Amending Act of 1958 was not applicable to the Bellary district.

arguments.claim: Levy is fee under original s.11(1), remit to High Court to determine if valid fee correlated to services rendered

arguments.court_reasoning: Validity as sales tax rejected, but remit for fee validity

holdings.text: The amendment made by the Mysore legislature in 1958 by which sub-s. (1) of s.11 was substituted by a new section did not apply to the Bellary district and was confined only to the Madras Area which meant the district of South Kanara with the exception of specified areas.

anchor.surface_text: We have no manner of doubt that the Bellary district which became a part of the State of Mysore as a result of the Central Act 30 of 1953 was governed by s. 11 1  of the Act as it stood at the time it had become applicable to that area by virtue of s. 53 of the aforesaid Central Act of 1953. The amendment made by the Mysore legislature in 1958 by which sub-s. 1  of II was substituted by a new section did number apply to the Bellary district

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statement of objects and reasons refers only to South Kanara; definition of 'Madras Area' in Mysore General Clauses Act excludes Bellary; s.154 of 1966 Act distinguishes Bellary from Madras Area; Bellary bye-laws exclude 1958-specified crops and rates.

holdings.text: The demand related to a fee which alone could be levied under s. 11(1) of the Act as originally stood, notwithstanding use of word 'cess' in notice.

anchor.surface_text: Under bye-law 19 the rate specified for groundnut seeds was 9 paise per kilogram. The notice sent by the Market Committee making the demand from the respondents employed the word cess but that cannot stand in the way of it being held that the demand related to a fee which alone could be levied under S. 11 1  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1958 amendment inapplicable to Bellary; rate matches bye-law 19 under original s.11(1) and s.19; word 'cess' does not alter nature as fee.

holdings.text: The demand by the Market Committee could be made lawfully only in respect of a fee; validity and legality of that levy to be determined by High Court including whether correlated to services rendered.

anchor.surface_text: As it has been determined by us that the demand by the Market Committee could be made lawfully only in respect of a fee the validity and legality of that levy will have to be determined by the High Court. The distinction between a fee and a tax is well known and there are a series of decisions of this Court on what is a fee and what are the tests

holdings.reasoning_summary: Levy under original provision is fee not tax; applies existing doctrine on fee-tax distinction (citing Delhi Cloth Mills); remands for factual determination of services correlation and evidence.

anchor.surface_text: We have no manner of doubt that the Bellary district which became a part of the State of Mysore as a result of the Central Act 30 of 1953 was governed by s. 11 1  of the Act as it stood at the time it had become applicable to that area by virtue of s. 53 of the aforesaid Central Act of 1953. The amendment made by the Mysore legislature in 1958 by which sub-s. 1  of II was substituted by a new section did number apply to the Bellary district
The appeals are allowed accordingly and the cases are remitted to the High Court for disposal.
